Do you love ignoring main quest?
Do you love having sex on stuffed animals?
Have you ever wanted to try on women clothes?
If you answered YES to any of those questions, this is the game for You.
You play as Geralt, a mutant with cat eyes and hair as pale as your malnourished flesh, that hasnéˆ¥æª› seen sun in a week, will be after finishing this game.
Story begins as Geralt embarks on a journey to find love of his life, but not before traveling through cities, farms and slums, taking on every monster contract in known world. Fist fighting everyone, forcing all humans and nonhumans to a round of Gwent.
The game offers well-crafted stories with choices that you make and which shape your journey. You can become a monster, who incites fear in everything living or not so... Or become Saint Gregory himself, a paragon of virtue who picks daisies, and helps to paint trollséˆ?fence.
The World éˆ?itéˆ¥æªš massive, as massive as the hole in your heart when you finish the game. Hundreds of locations, more NPCs to talk to than real life, each with their stories and quests to offeréˆ¥î›‡nd some even more than that, if you catch my meaning.
Gorgeous graphics and animations, superb voice acting. Your jaw will drop, more times than wind has howled. Each time you ride through city or see a mountain range immersion takes a hold of you, and after some time youéˆ¥æª’l never want to go outside again. Even the most mundane thing you do, will feel as if orchestra is following your every step, with three ladies yodeling about your every move.
Fighting will become a second nature to you, using swords, potions and signs to your advantage, reading books about monsters. Learning how to slay beasts for money and not getting your éˆ¾ãƒ¢æ«éˆ¾?killed in process is an experience only few games offer.
Witcher 3 aged like a fine wine. Considering games that have come out in past couple of years, this game will take a hold of you. You will be satiated - real life will seem bleak and boring. While being at school or work, only thing you will be thinking about is éˆ?how can I complete that contract and what armor should I wear for my next fight.
This game deserves every praise and your money in full.

The story was so immersive and addicting. The quests are so detailed and exciting and far better than the typical fetch quests RPG's seem to run into these days. Impressive character acting makes you care about the characters you interact with. The choices you make determine the path of not only you but the NPCs you meet throughout and it really puts this game in a league of its own. I highly recommend Witcher 3 to any player whose enjoys great story, characters, and addictive game play.

A co-worker had been recommending this game to me for years.  I'd been reluctant to play games on the PC that didn't include character control via the mouse.  I'd found it tough to coordinate fingers movements on the keyboard.  I finally decided to get out of my comfort zone and tried Witcher 3 Wild Hunt.  It was awkward at first, but after a short time .... well,I got better at it.  The game itself is very interesting and challenging.  I enjoy the character development and interactions, and fighting the uniquely imaginative monsters.  It may seem as a step back, but after I complete this game, I'll most likely get into Withcer 1 & 2.

I am a female player who loves a good story and great game play.  This game is the best combination of both I have ever seen.  The open world is amazingly, lovingly...almost mind-bogglingly detailed.  Every corner of every map has -something-.  The empty marsh with a forgotten secret treasure.  The unexpectedly beautiful vista after climbing a rise, standing out in such a stark contrast to the warn-torn countryside you've traveled through to get there.  Abandoned cabins which tell a story all of their own.  This is all the EXTRAS.  Places you do not have to visit. It's all just ...there, waiting to be discovered.
The quest design is brilliant.  Given the complexity of trying to make a story in an open world where you could find things completely in the wrong order, the designers are nearly flawless in the execution.
Most of all, controlling Geralt feels ...natural.  Much, much better than Witcher 2.  I am NOT a power gamer and yet I can easily crossbow an oncoming foe, cast a quick sign for protection and draw my blade to attack.  This is also the first game where riding a horse and piloting a small skiff works so well I don't mind doing it, even when sometimes I could quick travel.  There are some places that are just fun to gallop your horse through.  Or speed your boat through the waters.
The scope of this game is just breathtaking.   The story is dark and gritty, so much so that you wonder if the world isn't so completely messed up that you should just let the bad guys win.  But then there are those moments - and they are rare, true, but moments where you have a chance, if you want, to make a bit of hope.  Restore a village.  Save a merchant.  Bring a family back together.   You can't change the world - Kings will be éˆ¾ãƒ¢æ«éˆ¾ãƒ¢æ«éˆ?and wars will be wars - but you can do your part to make it better, one quest at a time.  This is the part that seems -most- analogous to our everyday real lives:  we can't stop politicians from being éˆ¾ãƒ¢æ«éˆ¾ãƒ¢æ«éˆ?or wars and violence from happening, but we can do our part to make the world a little better place, one day at a time.

I'm one of those people who's had the game for years and just never got around to playing it, oh how I regret not playing this gem till now, because even comparing it to newer games I can truly say this game is probably already in my top 10 games of all time. (only reason it's not top 3 is because multiplayer games are more my cup of tea)
The story and world is fleshed out, raw, mature, kinky and gruesome with little to no room for improvement, it's good enough that you end up reading all the flavor text, but you're not forced to closely read up on any of it to understand what's going on, you could probably just open most readable's once and the game will note down any important points you need later, bringing it up when you need it.
Combat is hard and unforgiving if you don't stock up on healing items, but a few skills can make healing items way to effective, I mean "food items last 20 min" who thought that sounded balanced.
Was hoping taking on certain types of monsters would require more preparation but at the same time I'm glad you're not totally boned if you're in combat with a ghost and didn't bring it's weakness with you.
Music is spot on luxury to the ears, though I did get enough of the combat theme after a while.
Leveling and gear is well thought out and can accommodate a wide range of playstyles, light armor for high  amounts of time spent combat rolling, heavy armor if you can't be asked to dodge even to save your life and medium for people with decent dodging skills but still want to live if they mess up a dodge.

It's a really good game, there is no doubt about that. Story, level design, graphics, and sound quality is top notch. My only complaint is the combat system. I wish it was more responsive, fluid and intuitive similar to Assassin's Creed, Sleeping Dogs or Batman Arkham Series.
The small fraction of the reviews are negative and most of them relates to this issue. If your main source of entertainment comes from combat then it might be hard to "get into" in your first hours. After a few hours the story grips you, and at that point, the game transforms into a high quality TV Show with constant cliffhangers which keeps you "hooked up" until the end.
I had that feeling almost in all Witcher games. Because CD Projekt Red didn't innovate much in combat mechanics. I hope they will overcome this in Cyberpunk 2077.

Playing the witcher 3 wild hunt so far has been a wonderful journey of losing myself in the engaging story and sprawling world. At first, as someone who had not played the prior two games, I was overwhelmed with both the complex story and game mechanics while confronted with countless avenues to take. After a few days of playing, I got the hang of things and eventually came to appreciate the beauty in the complexity and the joy of getting a handle on the mechanics. Whether it was figuring out how to effectively kill a monster with a specific play style or holding my own against multiple higher level enemies, each discovery has been as rewarding as the last. I'm just over 30 hours in and I have so much story left to finish. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a fantastical, RPG, open-world experience with a compelling story with slice of romance.
Game of the decade (2010-2020), perhaps even century (2000-2100)!

Even 5 years later, this game is an epic undertaking in storytelling and writing. Voice actors are (almost) all excellent. It really pushes the engine to its limit, in terms of the diversity of what all the character models and environmental assets are being asked to do. As compared to how things must have looked for the first couple weeks of this game, the tiny glitches that are still left are mostly graphical in nature - certainly not game-breaking, which is more than can be said of pretty much any other AAA game released since. Any 'grind' is pretty much unnoticeable, since there's something interesting for your character to do, no matter your level. Mod support is excellent, and the mod community is still active. The controls? Eh, at first, I hated the way 'spells' were cast and 'items' were used. However, now, I see that the game developer's goal was to force players to strategically predict encounters with enemies, and plan things out, rather than relying on pure reflexes and spamming buttons to win. The expansions are also badass. Great deal, overall - I spent $15 bucks on the whole collection on a steam sale, which I consider to be my best game purchase, yet. Minor quality-of-life annoyances are all easily fixed with mods. Would highly, highly recommend.

It is hard not to recommend this game. It offers a lot. I like the lore and the world in particular. There are times when I just walk around the city or the mountains to experience it as I would in real life. (I mean, who runs around nonstop for 3 hours and for 100 miles.) The combat is nice although it is quite easy. On normal and easy difficulty, I managed to survive battles without using potions, decoctions, and oils. I restarted the game without finishing the story and decided to play it in the hardest difficulty from Level 1. It made the game more fun for me. One thing I have issues though is movement for both Geralt and the horse (especially the horse). I was expecting a Red Dead Redemption kind of horse but what I got was a cockroach. The horse just can't keep on the road. It prefers bumping into a tree or heading into a cliff which of course it subsequently tries to avoid falling from. This happens a lot when I gallop. I hate it when it misses bridges too and tries to probably throw me into rivers. That being said, the games is great overall. Get it now.

This is the best game ever made. Sure, people might try it and find it disappointing or underwhelming. But even the finest art has critics. So if you don't like this game, I feel for you as I would feel for someone who is indifferent towards "The Starry Night" or "Stairway to Heaven" - pity. If you have the sensibility to appreciate everything this game has to offer, however, I feel envy, since you're in for a unique, unforgettable experience. The flaws are too minor to mention. Simply enjoy this masterpiece and pray CDProjekt continue making games like this one, because no one else does.

I think a lot of people would agree when I say that this game IS game of the decade. It's immersive, it set a new standard to open world character-driven narrative games, and most importantly, it's a nice big "éˆ¾ãƒ¢æ«éˆ¾ãƒ¢æ« you" to EA because, just as everyone with a brain knows, single player games are NOT dead. This game is a golden answer to that.
It is not without flaws, of course, but the flaws I found and experienced as I played through this game for nearly 400 hours is equivalent to sand between my toes while I enjoy my time at the beach éˆ?it's annoying to have them but it doesn't put a damper to everything else I experienced. This game is time and money well spent, truly revolutionary in a lot of aspects.
Some might say that God of War may be that game and I wouldn't blame them for it. It's just that, to me, the time I spent going in blind (I've yet to read the books and I went into this game without having played the previous ones) is definitely one of if not the most memorable moments of my life as someone who is a simple fan of video games.
Also, Yennefer is best girl. Thank you for coming to my TED Talk.

This game took me a little while to get into, not having played any other Witcher game before. There is a lot of backstory that I was unfamiliar with. Once I got several hours into the game, I got hooked. This is one of the richest worlds that I have ever encountered. The side missions do not feel like endless drudgery and actually contribute to the story. The main story line is great so far. I am really enjoying this game. Witcher 3 is by far the best RPG game that I played. The story is so immersive that it won't let go until you complete the game. The world is interesting to explore as there is always something new that will be found.  Even the side quest are interesting to complete as there is no dull side quest in this game. Character development is wonderful as it introduces to every character even if you haven played previous games (or read books). Completed the game in 130 hours and still 2 DLCs left. The game is worth every cent you pay for it. Loved it from the very beginning to the very end.

This game is one of the best, if not THE BEST RPG I have ever played in my 20+ years of gaming. If you have not given this game a shot what are you even doing with your life? Very few if any game bugs, quests are great and meaty side quests are fun and not just simple fetch quests or kill count quests. Dialogue is great sound design and music choices are perfect.
All in all I would easily give this game a 10/10 well worth it and I can only hope CDPR gets it this right for Cyberpunk when it comes out later this year.

This game is my favorite game I've ever played, and one of the best games ever made. Every side quest is engaging, there are no fetch quests. The main story is very good, the graphics hold up very well, and it is an all round great game. The amount of content you are getting for $40 is absolutely insane. I would recommend this game to anyone who has even the slightest interest in RPGs.

One of the best RPG's I have ever played and a strong contender for first place, that's coming from someone who regards RPG's as their favourite genre since the PS1 era and has played most AAA RPG's released since the 2000's. The combat is complex but smooth and satisfying once you master it, I completed the game on death march(hardest difficults) with relative ease once I got going, not because it was easy, but the game rewards you for playing well and smart by not getting hit and exploiting enemy weaknesses by using signs(magic), potions and oils and good timing. The graphics are fantastic, the voice acting is fantastic, the story is fantastic, and aimed at a mature audience. There is SO much content to discover and the DLC's add dozens of hours more. I fell in love with the characters and the story so much I even bought the books. The only fault I can point out in this game is that there is SO much to do you can feel overwhelmed and get burnout. You can tell the developers poured their heart into this game and they did a fantastic job, well done CD Projekt.
There are also naked ladies.  10/10

A game so good I've brought it more than once (though still 20 short of Skyrim which should be released on my microwave soon).
The thing about the Witcher 3 which sets is apart from the rest is a level of craftsmanship in the world from the main quests, side quest, general world building and random encounters. For example, I was attach by some random bandits on horseback near Velen and I killed them with ease. Went ahead and looted their camp only to find a letter from one of the bandits to their wife which mentioned bringing something home for the young'un from their "da". It got me thinking and whilst a small addition to the game, it makes you think about how these bandits are people beyond simple video-game fodder.
Other endearing parts of the game are the easter eggs and callbacks to previous games (for those who played Witcher 1/2 like myself). If you've seen the Monty Python films, you might notice a certain conversation from beggars in Novigrad where one is complaining about being cured and it affecting their work.
Overall, one of my favourite games outside of the Mass Effect series and I'm really enjoying my current re-playthrough.

Some say that video games are an art form, people outside the industry are often quick to scoff at the idea. This game demonstrates that great video games are the definitive medium to tell the best stories. Movies and book have each their elegant charm but this game is something special, both the greatest book and the greatest movie ever created. All rolled in a living, evolving world that in the moment you can easily forget you aren't a part of. This was my first experience with the products of this developer. I will be spending 100s of dollars to make sure that I can be a part of the next one.

Best game of the decade

Never understood how a game could be "too long" until I played this game.
The sheer number of side quests the base game itself offers is insane, and of actually good quality, length, and story development, unlike most fetch quests games of this genre may usually suffer from. The main story itself is good too, though you'll likely find yourself ignoring the questline as exclamation points or question marks constantly pop up as you even make your way to the next destination. Before you know it, you've spent 2 hours on finishing side quests and contracts, and playing gwent alone.
Another thing that makes the story stand out is the fact that choices actually feel like they have impact in this game. Missing or ignoring certain side quests, or choosing bad options during the game can drastically affect the outcome of the game in terms of its lore (if you care about that). Also, you may miss out on certain gwent cards which is a massive rip. As such, you live with your decisions, something games for some reason find difficult to make work.
The overall environment looks beautiful and cutscenes, especially *certain* ones, are very well animated, making the game feel more immersive as a whole. The OST, characters, and "herbs schmerbs, but how 'bout some gwent" are great.
Also, have I mentioned to you how great gwent is?

The Witcher is as attractive as it is inelegant, immersive as it is clumsy, one of the best stories wrapped in one of the worse games ever.
The combat is completely unrewarding. There is no skill in this combat system. It's repeating simple patterns and damage adjustment based on level scaling.
The equipment is pointless. Your swords will be 10 levels past their prime for hours of gameplay. Run three witch bounties and you'll replace your original and two of the bounty sword rewards in 30 minutes.
The story doesn't care about how you play. There is no time or performance penalty. Racing an NPC? You're fine to stand around for 30 minutes then run through normally and win.
Don't even bother learning the combat system. Just dodge and fast attack, dodge and fast attack....
Even though one of the worst video games ever is standing in the way of the story and setting, it is still one of the best and immersive worlds. It is familiar, original, and delivers.

This game is definitely one of the best games I have ever played. The amount of care, detail, and attention put into everything is absurd. Every sidequest, even the most mundane ones, have charm and meaning to them. Every structure you find has a story behind it. All the enemies have unique and interesting designs and mechanics. The world is absolutely beautiful and is a wonderfully realistic and immersive setting. Novigrad is easily my favorite video game city of all time.
But I do not understand the unending praise this game gets.
Don't get me wrong. This game is absolutely fantastic. But this game is not a masterpiece. You hear this term just about everywhere, but it's a flawed gem. No game is perfect. Every game has problems. And the Witcher 3 has some annoying, hard to ignore problems.
The combat, for a game of this scale, is pretty great. It's clunky at first but you get a hang of it after a while. It's complete éˆ¾ãƒ¢æ«éˆ¾?when fighting multiple enemies though. Those Wild Hunt Hounds are absolute hell to fight in packs. Hitboxes can be occasionally janky and enemy telegraphs aren't clear a lot of the time. The biggest problem with the combat, however, is that after a certain point it becomes way too easy. I was playing on the second highest difficulty and I was spam clicking just about every enemy without much trouble. The only things that challenged me were the three big bosses you face towards the end of the game. I really liked the feeling in the opening of the game where you had to prepare before a big fight. Brew a bunch of potions, buy food, temper your weapons, etc... and you do that for like 4 more levels and you don't have to anymore. Really wish that feeling was consistent throughout the game.
I find that the story loses some of its stride after the climax. It becomes a generic save the world plot - more about stopping the big bad than about developing characters or finding new interesting ones. There's really only three characters other than Geralt that see development during the final act. It's a real step down from when you were travelling across the Northern Realms, finding old and new friends, discovering their motivations, and watching them have actual character development. Just kinda stagnated towards the end. Also the ending is meh. Really could've used more explanation and there was some stuff that just... made no sense. The ending wasn't offensive, it was just 'whelming'.
I. Hate. The. Minimap. It's bad. Since nearly every single quest has a location objective where you have to travel somewhere through complex road systems (getting Roach through a forest or swamp is a pain in the éˆ¾ãƒ¢æ«éˆ¾?so taking the roads are just easier), you have to heavily rely on the minimap's little dotted line telling you where to go. This is bad. You end up looking at the minimap 50% of the time. It's more difficult to immerse yourself in this beautiful world when you're not looking at it half the time. I turned off the minimap which greatly improved my experience, but I still had to open the map a lot to know where I'm going. It was pretty satisfying when in Novigrad I memorized the streets so I only had to glance at the map once or twice though.
I won't be going in depth about the pros of the game because I'm sure every review here will do that for you. I do still highly recommend this game. I'd say its a must-play.
One warning though: If you're looking to play a game that's about exploration first, story second, this ain't it. You'll still enjoy it but it won't be what you expect. At the time of this review, just a few months separate us from the fifth anniversary of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt. The game has been called out by many to be the game of the decade, and I've decided to do a short no-spoilers retrospection on why is that the case. All of this coming from a player that hasn't even started his first NG+. PS.: I intended to keep this review short, but as I couldn't, I will include a TL;DR section below, targeted specifically to people that have not yet decided on whether to buy the game or not.
As you play as Geralt of Rivia, an already fleshed out character with its own personality and acquaintances right from the start, I would not dare call this game an RPG, but it is far simpler than saying that it is a "story driven action game with lots of decisions to make, some of which may have bigger or lesser impacts on the main story. Oh and you have lots of character progression, with various skill trees you can choose abilities from as well as lots of bombs, oils, potions, weapons and armor you can craft with materials you gather along your journey".
This RPG aspects of the game might drive out players that don't enjoy the genre, but it is very likely that they fall in love with any other aspect of the game. Aside from that, the game has four difficulties in total, and only the highest one REALLY demand you to make full use of these aspects to have an advantage; the other two allow you to have the upper hand whether you utilize the games' mechanics at full or not.
The combat is pretty basic, but it is very exciting and has a fluidity that makes up fully for its lack of depth. Combine that with any battle music track that the game rocks, and you will have an epic fight even against a simple drowner.
The music, as already foreseen, is simply amazing. I genuinely did not have any moment where I thought "hey this track is somewhat lackluster". Hell, there was this one time that I ended up humming 'Merchants of Novigrad' all day (for those who do not know, Novigrad is an important city of the game, and what I mentioned is an ambient music track played on said city). As I do not have any intricate thoughts on the matter, I beckon it will suffice to say that The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stars one of the best soundtracks that I have ever listened to on a video game. Who woulda thunk.
Even though you play the role of an already built character with relationships of his own, the games' story and general narrative are incredibly enjoyable, not to mention that you still have a whole lot of decisions that build on Geralts' personality and make him a different character overall. Geralt is a really good main character, and he is one of the main reasons I keep playing the game. He's cool and interesting, his insights on various situations and his conversations with almost every character made me really want to flesh out his character and get to know his personality and relationships. The game has a large amount of secondary quests and contracts, and almost every change of track on your adventures rewards you something.
And we yet have to disclose graphics. The game was for me an INFINITELY immersing experience from the beginning. While you travel through the world you will encounter a lot, believe me, A LOT of incredibly beautiful places, landscapes and towns. I really recommend playing on High graphic settings, even at the expense of some frames if you don't have a high-end PC. Halfway through the game I just ramped up my settings just for the sake of even more beautiful landscapes, and at least for me, 50+ FPS is already an amazingly cinematic experience. Just the view from the balcony at Kaer Morhen on the very first scene of the game told me this was going to be a beautiful experience.
And it was just that. From joy to grief, from sadness to excitement, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt made me feel a lot of different things. I really recommend that you play the game without spoiling yourself anything. The emotional spikes hit harder that way, and it really helps that you involve yourself on the narrative and on the characters' problems.
The only things I found to be issues to me were horse traveling, minor problems with the 'enemy upscaling' feature (on a certain djinn fight specifically), the underdeveloped character that was our main antagonist, and that the urgency of the main quest is not reflected on Geralts' journey (this, from my point of view, was inevitable, given the type of game the developers wanted to build, and the main quests' theme on the other side of the table). Two of those issues I cannot refer to due to my 'no-spoiler' disclosure, but they don't affect how the game feels AT ALL. And don't misinterpret me, the horse traveling isn't bad at all, in fact it is really good and it achieves its purpose. The only thing that bothered me were those moments where the horse randomly stopped while galloping, which lead me to just canter, and keep enjoying the scenery. A good thing overall, I guess.
TL;DR: TW3 is a must-try game. It goes really cheap for what it is on sales, and if it doesn't really hurt your pocket, then you must ABSOLUTELY try it. If it doesn't catch you when finishing the first act, then you can reconsider. If it is the RPG aspects that scare you, then believe me that they are not a big deal, specially on easier difficulties. They might even draw you into them as you play the game. TW3 rocks an amazingly good soundtrack, beautiful landscapes, and fluid combat. In this review I couldn't stress enough everything that I felt while playing the game, nor I was able to comment on every well done aspect the game has.
And that 'sums up' my experience. Please forgive my abuse of the same adjectives on multiple parts of the review, and my redacting skills. I didn't really intend to make it this long. If you have any recommendations, things to add or points to discuss, please feel free to leave a comment!

This game isn't perfect. Still one of the best games I've ever played. The depth of every story is incredible, even in the scraps of paper you find on the side of a road. The quests are satisfying without exception, even when they're glorified fetch missions, simply because the dialogue is so engaging.
Combat is quite simple, but never feels boring. Getting new potions, oils and decoctions feels rewarding. The skill trees have their flaws (some early game perks are broken, some late game perks are terrible), but overall make it feel worthwhile to try different builds for the fun of it (even on the hardest difficulty, nothing is brutally challenging without mods).
Recommended for anyone who likes a very intricate story where most of your decisions, no matter how large or small, have an impact. Fans of series like KOTR will adore this game.

A very gripping story, especially for those familiar with Sapkowski's stories and novels. Very variable quests all through the game, you never get the feeling of "just another boring monster slaying, herb collecting" or whatnot. The only tiny flaw might be the character development system, stat/attribute/combat bonus display system and random item generation system which are simply wanting, even though relatively elegant at the same time. But combat itself, along with all the various animations, is simply fluid and beautiful, especially on harder difficulties it is challenging all the way through the game. And the graphics is stunning for now several-years-old game.
All in all, I must repeat what I had been told before I purchased the game on numerous occasions - a TRUE must-have for all fans of RPG genre and much recommended even to those who only play such games on special occasions.
And by the way, the built-in collectible card game of gwent is in itself a masterpiece in simplicity and elegance.

People call this the best RPG/Open world game ever created, I think that's overrating this game. Personally I prefer the first 2 games in the series since they followed a non-linear "act" based format instead of Open World.
It's already been said a million times but the graphics, writing, sound, music are great. So I won't go deep into that.
The locations and visuals are a downgrade from Witcher 2. I mean go back to Flotsam Forest in W2 and then back into W3's "Trees and a random copy paste village in between open world"
It does suffer a bit from Ubisoft syndrome where there's a lot of copy and paste activities sprinkled around the map but they can be easily ignored if you want and it's best to focus on side quests and Witcher contracts. The weakest quest types are usually treasure/scavenger hunts.
Crafting/Alchemy is still under developed and bloated. On the bright side, the game is incredibly long to support them this time, since Witcher 2 was 20-30 hours long. The movement, animations, horse controls etc are really average compared to most third person games.  The Combat is a slightly improved Witcher 2, never has and never will be great.
Trust me for someone who has played the first and the second games for over a decade, the series has always been carried by it's storyline, characters and writing. The Witcher has always been a gloried walking simulator and I'm okay with that. Yennifer, Bloody Baron, The Crones and Ciri are the highlights here.
The games first part which takes place in Velen is some of the best stuff I've seen in the series. However, once you reach Novigrad you'll experience what I found to be the weakest part of the game. The problem is the whole Dandelion part being dragged on probably even breaking the record for way too many fetch quests. Considering the game has another island to explore after that, you could get burned out especially if you're unfamiliar with the first 2 games. Also the whole "roleplaying" and choice making doesn't seem to effect you drastically in this game beyond choosing how big of a prick you want Geralt to be.
The weakest part of the entire game though is Eredin and everything to do with the Wild Hunt. Three freaking games for it to play out this way? Why did he have to take off his mask? Yes Letho and Geralt talk about the Wild Hunt being Aen Elle but I would have preferred if they still maintained some kind of mystic around him. I remember being excited back in 2007 and not being familiar with the books thinking that the Wild Hunt was going to be a rendition of the myth of the dead army that roams across the sky.
Game is incredibly long, being an open world game, the 80% of your playtime will be you getting from point A to Point B. I enjoyed it but actually did see myself getting burned out by the time I finished the main story, Heart Of Stone and it's sidequests to move on to Blood and Wine which takes place in Toussaint.
My recommendation is to play Blood and Wine after taking a break from finishing Main game and HOS. Heart Of Stone is the second highlight of the game, first being the Baron/Crones questline. Another highlight is Gwent being far better than dice as a minigame this time around.
Verdict: While I think the third game is probably the weakest, and the series never managed to get combat/crafting right it's a great end to one of my favourite game trilogies.

The DLC tho? that's the best part, the Blood And Wine DLC is perfect and Heart of Stone DLC is mysteriously awesome
my final rating for this game is 10/10
